content.webTitle: Oliver Heald on working at a hostel for homeless men

fields.headline: Reality bytes
fields.bodyText: My induction [at St Anne's hostel] left me a bit nervous as Mandy, deputy manageress, mentioned the possible risks of needle stick injury and violence. In the TV room, the most popular programme was Location, Location, Location. We walk to the Archer Project and tearoom. Six men are waiting for it to open. They are freezing cold. The talk is about tonight's weather forecast, with seven inches of snow expected. One man is pleased he has a good thick coat. Another wonders where he'll get enough cardboard to make a shelter good enough for snow. The best thing has been talking to the residents. Although some of their troubles could be described as self-inflicted, particularly the drink and drug problems, many here have had a bad start in life. Mental illness, particularly depression, features with many. I talk to a 40-year-old with scars all over his arms after years of self-harm. The problem of basic skills keeps coming up. One young man is having trouble budgeting. He's never known how to do arithmetic. What strikes me is how much progress they can make with help. As a society, we need to expand anti-addiction services, support families better, and give mental health needs greater priority. · Full blog at: centreforsocialjustice.org.uk
